claim: Ninjas likely wore clothing that helped them blend into their surroundings, rather than all black as often depicted in popular culture.

supporting.text: Historical records suggest ninjas often wore dark blue or brown clothing, which blended better with nighttime environments than pure black.

attacks.text: Historical records suggest ninjas often wore dark blue or brown clothing, which blended better with nighttime environments than pure black.
Some historical accounts describe ninjas wearing black for specific missions where it was advantageous.
The accounts of black clothing may be later exaggerations or conflations with theatrical depictions.
Dark blue and brown would not have provided sufficient camouflage in all nighttime environments.
Ninjas would have adapted their clothing to specific environments and missions, not relying on a single color.

supporting.text: Ninjas operated in rural and forested areas, where dark blue or earth-toned clothing would provide better camouflage than stark black.

attacks.text: Ninjas operated in rural and forested areas, where dark blue or earth-toned clothing would provide better camouflage than stark black.
Historical records from the Edo period describe ninjas wearing black clothing to blend into shadows at night, contradicting the rural camouflage claim.
Ninja missions often occurred at night when black clothing would be more effective for concealment, regardless of rural settings.
Surviving ninja manuals like the Bansenshukai explicitly recommend dark blue for rural camouflage, supporting A2's claim.
Modern color science confirms dark blue blends better with moonlit landscapes than pure black, which creates harsh silhouettes.

supporting.text: Some historical depictions and texts mention ninjas wearing black clothing, aligning with the popular cultural image.

attacks.text: Some historical depictions and texts mention ninjas wearing black clothing, aligning with the popular cultural image.
Historical depictions are often influenced by theater, where black clothing symbolized invisibility rather than actual ninja attire.
Theater conventions are not reliable evidence for real-world ninja practices, as they were artistic interpretations.
Surviving ninja manuals and texts emphasize camouflage matching the environment, not fixed black clothing.
Black dye was expensive and impractical for nighttime operations, making dark blue or brown more likely.

supporting.text: Black clothing stands out in moonlight, whereas darker shades of blue or gray are more effective for concealment, a practical consideration for ninjas.

attacks.text: Black clothing stands out in moonlight, whereas darker shades of blue or gray are more effective for concealment, a practical consideration for ninjas.
Ninjas primarily operated at night, where black clothing would blend into shadows more effectively than blue or gray.
Historical records suggest ninjas often disguised themselves as civilians or monks, making color choices situational rather than fixed.
Dyes for true black clothing were rare and expensive in feudal Japan, making widespread use by ninjas unlikely.
Ninja equipment lists from period scrolls include dark blue garments, supporting the practicality argument.

supporting.text: Theatrical traditions, such as kabuki, used black costumes to represent invisibility, which may have influenced the popular depiction of ninjas in all black.

attacks.text: Theatrical traditions, such as kabuki, used black costumes to represent invisibility, which may have influenced the popular depiction of ninjas in all black.
Kabuki theater and ninja practices were culturally distinct, and there is little evidence that theatrical conventions directly influenced historical ninja attire.
Historical records suggest ninjas wore dark blue or brown clothing for better camouflage at night, not pure black.
The association of black with invisibility in kabuki could have seeped into broader cultural perceptions, including those of ninjas, even without direct historical linkage.
Ninjas were often farmers or mercenaries who used practical disguises, making theatrical depictions less relevant to their actual attire.

supporting.text: Ninjas prioritized practicality, and clothing that matched common peasant attire (dark blues, browns) would have been more effective for blending in.

attacks.text: Ninjas prioritized practicality, and clothing that matched common peasant attire (dark blues, browns) would have been more effective for blending in.
Historical records from the Edo period describe ninjas wearing all-black outfits for night operations, contradicting the idea that they avoided black clothing.
The 'all-black' depiction may have been exaggerated in theater and art, but it originated from some basis in reality for specific missions.
Peasant attire varied by region and season, so there was no single 'common' disguise that would work universally for ninjas.
Ninjas also operated as spies in castles and towns, where all-black clothing would stand out more than peasant attire.
